ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: You learn about signal & image processing and various models for how computers and brains actually see.

Was a great way to tie in mathematical concepts I knew already with biological concepts I knew already. Fascinating overlap between the two and how modern computation is heavily inspired from biological concepts.

I learned a ton in this course! This showed me some of the most beautiful applications of mathematics to the natural world and our observations of it I have ever seen. You learn a ton about how to think about breaking down issues in visual recognition and how your brain might actually do some of these things on biological hardware. Computational and mathematical techniques, as well as equivalents in neuroscience.
biological perception

I learned quite a bit about the brain's visual systems and how the underlying circuitry can be compared and contrasted to that of popular computer vision techniques, including state-of-the-art methodologies in convolutional neural networks.
Basic machine learning concepts, neural networks, backpropagation, and its connection with human/animal vision
Grab bag of computer vision, machine learning inspired by neuroscience.
Artificial intelligence with regards to applications to vision, with small subjects building into larger image classification algorithms.
I learned about a variety of topics relating to neuroscience and machine learning/AI.
Very broad course that goes over things from limulus to neural networks and fourier transforms.

Biological origins and intuitions of modern ML algorithms, where ML algorithms fall short compared to biological systems, visual neurobiology, edge detection, neural connectivity, PCA, history of vision algorithms, stereo vision, image filters
A new found knowledge of how computers and cells comprehend and manipulate images. Also improved my python skills.
Concepts of vision described mathematically

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
The content is really interesting. It's really interesting to see the parallels between computer vision and human vision, and see how we learn about each from the other.

Actually, the content is FASCINATING!

However, everything else about this class is a mess. There is 0 communication among the teaching staff. The one TA was out of the country for the entire semester and only would hold office hours at inconvenient times on Zoom. 
24 hours before the midterm exam, the professor discovered that we had not received even a single graded assignment (and only because we told him in class).
It is not clear at all how to study for the exams. There are no example problems or even a specific list of topics or ideas that might be on the exam.

Zucker's lectures are totally unstructured. From the start of lecture to the end it's just a high-speed whirlwind stream-of-consciousness developing ideas, but without any meaningful preface of what those ideas are supposed to be. I could never expect where a lecture would end based on where it began. It is not clear at all which ideas are important, or even the main ideas. Zucker's math is all very handwavey, his notation is never consistent. His lecture notes are long, rambling, and also lack any notational consistency.

Truly though, the content of the class really is deeply interesting. The neurological and computational ideas that are presented are really beautiful, it's just often hard to see them.

This course was well taught but not at all organized, many homework assignments were returned months after they were due and their was very little feedback on them. Expectations on exams were not clear and there was not a lot of support for the students.
Strong applications for this, the homeworks were not very applicable to the exams though.

Weaknesses: the course was a little disorganized in terms of the communication between the prof and TAs. E.g. it often took a very long time for us to get grades back on assignments, and the prof always seemed surprised and unaware that this was the case. Because different TAs graded different things, the grading was also inconsistent on PSets vs. tests, for example.
Strengths: the main strengths of this course were the content and the professor. The content was beautiful and fascinating, and the professor was funny, warm, caring, smart, and passionate.
office hours literally not available, too much emphasis on math and memorization in the exams

Professor Zucker is a huge strength of this course. His humor and enthusiasm for the material shined through and made lectures very engaging. The homework assignments were interesting as well and an appropriate level of challenge. The only difficulty, which may just be a function of the material, was that if one got behind in a lecture it was pretty challenging to catch up. That being said, slides were available for all of the content and lecture notes for most of it, so I wouldn't recommend that the course material be condensed much at all. Another weakness was that it was slightly unclear how much of the (extremely-dense) content on the slides was meant to be memorized for exams, although the guidelines in review sessions were helpful. The last problem was a frankly ridiculous lack of grading on the part of the TA, but this was out of Professor Zucker's control.

Strength: very interesting material
Weakness: terribly organized, impossible to follow

Very disorganized lectures and notes make it difficult to understand what knowledge we're expected to know.
The professor is extremely passionate about the subject.

Strengths: imo, the material is super interesting. And the way everything comes together at the end shows a thoughtfulness in organizing the material to teach students a highly complex process in pretty high detail. Exams are well written, so dont feel like you need to memorize all material. Focus on the crucial parts

Weaknesses: however, Professor Zucker is not that great a lecturer; his notes and lecture style are highly disorganized. Lecture notes are often incomplete (including empty sections and sentences that just cut off) and accompanying slides have almost no information to be able to follow off of. If you dont go to lecture, its impossible to follow along the course. And his lectures are often meandering and hard to follow.

The material taught in this class is very interesting, and the problem sets are engaging and relatively straightforward. However, the course is relatively weak in terms of the lecture slides, and could benefit through recorded lectures or more thorough slides.

Strengths: a lot of interesting material, and problem set were well written and interesting (and not too challenging).

Weaknesses: the lectures were given at a very fast pace and there was usually too much content to absorb most of it in the lecture.
Lectures not engaging, hard to follow because the information is disorganized. Would be better if they kept a bigger picture in mind

Super interesting content but the lectures were quite dense and hard to follow. I wish I had more math knowledge coming in, especially of linear algebra. The psets can be hard to understand but once you spend some time with it, the content is actually really interesting.

Strengths: 
- Lectures are taught in logical order from most simple to most complex
- Strong focus on math as opposed to just coding
- Interesting content and tangible connections to biological systems
- Science credit for CS and CS-adjacent majors
Weaknesses: 
- Grading was never punctual, and homework solutions were never released because the problems are reused every year. As I type this, I have a final grade but the last two homeworks and final exam are not in Canvas. 
- Homeworks were on the easier side and not very effective at reinforcing the rigorous lectures. I honestly feel like the Jupyter notebook/Matlab-based assignments would be bespoke freshman-level material. It was always simple to complete, but not very engaging.

This course has great lectures and interesting material. Steve Zucker is also a really nice guy and is haply to answer all questions. 

I wish there was some provided exam prep material.
lectures and homework were useful

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments:
If you have a specific interest in computer vision, this class might be for you, though I think that there are other ones on the subject as well.

If you're just looking for a CS elective, I wouldn't recommend this class.

It is an interesting elective but you have to be very self motivated to do well in this class and put in a lot of work outside of class and the materials given to understand what is going on in the lectures.

Pretty interesting class taking mostly by CS students. I was BME and in a strong minority. However, you can code everything using Matlab so don't be afraid to take this course (plus a lot of the topics like FT, convolution, etc,... are covered in other BME classes so you have a strong background already). You do not get any feedback on your exams or homework though and grading is slow.
Yes! The content is mind-blowing and the prof is awesome.
no

I would definitely recommend this course! Professor Zucker is quite engaging and the topic, although one I hadn't really learned much about before, is really fascinating. It is also comparatively low workload for anyone concerned about that. I know this is often a course CS students take for a science credit, but it is genuinely worth it and contains lots of interesting CS content as well. As a computational biology student I will admit that this course played well to my interests, but I also did not come into the semester planning on taking it and was sold by the two lectures I intended during add/drop. So at the very least I'd encourage anyone to try attending a couple of classes before counting it outl.
I would sincerely advise NOT to take this course, its horribly organized and you end up having to study everything yourself in a sea of unreadable notes
I would not recommend this course unless they have extensive background knowledge in neuroscience and computer vision.
No, even if you need the science credit for the CS major

I would recommend this course, as the material is quite interesting. However, I would also warn anyone planning to take this course to have a strong background in linear algebra and some experience programming.
I would recommend this course if in the future the lectures went a little bit more slowly and if there were more office hours/opportunities to engage with the course.

Not particularly, unless you truly enjoy the content and enjoy lectures that gloss really quickly over everything. The notes provided in suplement to the lectures are really helpful to read, but theyre unfinished. The lecture slides are quite messy though.

Yes, the class is unique, interesting, and logical in how content is taught and built upon. As a ML enthusiast, it was very interesting to see how modern algorithms fall short compared to their biological analogues.
I would definitely recommend this class to any cs majors looking for a science credit.
Yes, very interesting subject
